a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:47): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: I think the biggest positive effect of WD publication is that it gets documents a lot wider attention than just editor's-draft publication does
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:48): at least as far as W3C publication goes
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:48): and for a certain period of time, at least
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:48): in the context of HTML5, I have not seen it result in a higher level of technical review
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:48): yeah
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:48): though it does get some sort of attention in the tech press

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:50): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: yeah, the downside of that is that one of the first questions all the media people seem to ask every time W3C publishes and HTML5 WD is that, "OK, so when will HTML5 be done?" question
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:51): to which it seems to me the only proper response is to try to get them to see that they're asking the wrong question
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:51): but that's not usually successfull
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:51): then we can just point to the charter and indicate that the next milestone is Last Call
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:51): which is on schedule, so long as we can invent time travel technology in the next few months

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:53): the ietf guys argued that websocket would get wider review if we went through the ietf, but so far all the useful feedback i've received has been either off-list or on the whatwg list
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:54): similar to how it was argued that html5 would get more review if we went through the w3c
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:54): looks to me like the standards organisations are out of date in terms of what gets wider useful feedback :-)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:55): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I sent useful feedback on the ietf list... I think
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:56): i think everything you said on the list you first said on the adam/you/me thread we had
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:56): and adam and you would have reviewed the spec anyway, regardless of whether we went w3c, whatwg, or ietf
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:56): nah, I pointed out the reverse cross-protocol problem on the list first, then discussed it with you on IRC, then on the email thread with Adam
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:56): I would like to say I would have given that feedback anyway but I only thought of it due to people questioning the handshake
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:57): fair enough

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:57): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: standards organizations are out of date in a lot of ways.. I guess until we actually work on coming up with viable alternative, we are stuck with what we got, and hopefully at least we can (or have) managed to get some improvements made
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:57): I mean, I might have still had the thought
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:58): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: my most successful standard i think has been pingback, which didn't involve a standards organisation at all
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:58): it's not clear to me how to make a good standards org
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:58): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: so it's not clear to me that we _need_ an alternative
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (03:58): I think the existence of the Web Sockets discussion at IETF has helped to changed the IETF culture for the better
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:58): all the existing ones either come down to pay-to-play voting or dictatorship by an elite oligarchy, if you push hard enough
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:59): really? how so?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:59): er, that was to mike

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:59): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: i think the oligarchy mechanism is the only one that truly works, but it only works so long as the oligarchy has the respect of the implementors

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:00): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: and i think it pretty much stops having the respect as soon as there's a process in place, because a process forcibly distances the oligarchy from the implementors
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:00): part of the problem the w3c and ietf both have is that they try to solve too many problems at once
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:00): having multiple focus areas is a huge red flag for a std org imho
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (04:00): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I think the implementors issue is something that the Web Sockets work has helped to raise awareness about in the IETF
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:01): oligarchy can work with the right oligarchs
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:01): and so long as it does not get overwhelmed with legitimacy disputes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:01): legitimacy disputes = lack of respect

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (04:02): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: the awareness being that it is risky to develop a spec without also working hard to get implementor buy-in during the spec-development process
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:02): IETF and W3C try to have consensus/voting as the front line decision-making tool, with escalation to a dictator/oligarchy
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:02): sometimes I wonder if the other way around would work better
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:02): of course, in the HTML WG we kinda have a sandwich
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:02): not really
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:03): we just have three tiers of <span>abort the
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:03): er
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:03): mispaste
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:03): we just have three tiers of oligarchy
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:03): I guess layers at least limit the damage that can be done by any one layer going off the rails
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:04): each tier being further removed from the issues, leading to more and more random resolutions as an issue is escalated ;-)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (04:05): I find I need to have a lot more familiarity with the issues than I think I should have to for my role
